WHAT DID EARLY CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. H. Hill
Address: Charles Sask.
Birthplace: Ayrshire Scotland

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1911
Where did you set up housekeeping? Carleton Saskatchewan
Where had you been living before that? Toronto Ontario 1906
For how many people did you prepare meals? 4
How far was it to your nearest store? 2 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? when the grocer came out
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? flour, coal, oil, oatmeal, salt, matches, dried fruit, tobacco, and hardware.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? The grain grown gold Dust & the cheapest we could buy from 50¢ to $1.25
In what quantities did you buy it? 1 sack at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 80¢
How much did you use graham flour? 0
Whole wheat flour? yes
Was flour milled locally? no
How far away? Didn't know
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 80¢ to 65¢
What other grain products did you use? corn meal
Corn meal? yes
Whole wheat? flour
Parina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? We had no land cleared
How did you grind it? To grow wheat for 3 years. It wasn't there.
1. **INTRODUCTION**

   Fill in the blank or fill in the numbers on your own and mail it.

   **Questions:**
   - Where did you start homesteading in eastern Canada?
   - How many people did you have living there?
   - For how many years did you live there?
   - How far was it from your nearest town?
   - How often could a visit be made to the store?

   **Answers:**
   - In 1911, I started homesteading in eastern Canada.
   - I had five people living there.
   - We lived there for three years.
   - It was about two miles from the nearest town.
   - We visited the store once a month.

2. **FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS**

   - How much flour did you use in the last year?
   - What kind of flour did you buy?
   - How much did you pay per hundred pounds of flour?
   - How much did you use in the last year?
   - Was flour milled locally?
   - What was the price for a twenty-pound bag?
   - What other grain products did you use?
   - Did you grow your own?
   - Did you trade your own wheat for flour?
   - How did you grind it?

   **Answers:**
   - We used about 50 pounds of flour in the last year.
   - We bought flour from the local mill.
   - The price was $0.50 per hundred pounds.
   - We used about 50 pounds of flour in the last year.
   - No, we didn't grow our own wheat.
   - The price was $0.50 per twenty-pound bag.
   - We used corn meal, oats, and rye.
   - We didn't grow our own.
   - No, we didn't trade our own wheat for flour.
   - We ground it ourselves.
Dear Mr. Hill,

I am writing to express my gratitude for your kindness and support during our recent visit to your establishment. Your staff was incredibly attentive and friendly, making our stay comfortable and enjoyable.

We particularly appreciated the attention to detail in the presentation of your products. The quality of the food was excellent, and we were impressed by the cleanliness and organization of the premises.

Thank you again for your hospitality. We look forward to visiting you once more.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

P.S. Please accept our apologies for any inconvenience caused during our stay.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the number of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

For breakfast use our Scotch oatmeal porridge & tea & toast eggs or fruit if we had it
Dinner a good pot of soup & potatoes & meat either boiled or steamed if the soup was made with a bone supper, fried potatoes, cold meat, tea & milk.
the boys were young 13, 11, 8 & 3 & took a lot of milk.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? .................Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

A moose meat roast with a cennie vegetable & some nice brown gravy & a sweet pudding with vanilla sauce. There was my husband & two children & the cook & myself.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Now nor once we were down to the last morsel.
It's true I've been many years for 20 ounces in a country where there was no road when it rain all summer.
If you remember the wet summer 1912 was when the cyclone struck Regina. It never forget. I could not homestead again if they gave me all the land in the Dominion, One could not stand it any more nor once we got a good farm now & all the boys are men once we & good farms now & children farmers & oldest of the 4 is 27 yrs.
Next 50 for next 4 & the youngest is 41 so you will hear an idea how cold the winter is & of the boys and sisters in first & last war.
In the early days you got a Cotton Jack with a lot of the grease coat & corn meal花样酱料 in a wooden box.

For Breakfast we ate Scratch, Cold Meat Porridge & tea or coffee or fruit if we had it.

Dinner a good Pot of Beef & Potatoes & potato either boiled or steamed if the stuff was made with a bone further fried Potato Cold meat from month the top was young.

That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

A great meal Roast with a Creepie Vegetable & some nice brown gravy & a sweet pudding cut Grilled sauce that was good food and a bottle of beer for your us The most ever be my dear so quickly.

Here you were forced to almost starvation level food.

Once we were down to the last meal on our own product foods? Give details.

It's Butti a chance to get a farm for 10 Dollar in a country where they could claim all summer if you remember the old farmer 1912 was when the Cyclone struck Regina & many forget it would not have stood a rain if they gave me all the land in the Dominion, One crewed not stand it any more once we got good grain now to all the boys are grown by farmers to buy Pretty good the oldest of the 4 boys.

Next year I'm going to try to get the top land in am goin' to buy Cold the sitin' is 80. The top land in great to last war.
The homesteaders do young people would never do what we had to do; they don't know they lost so they can't work. We had to scrub all summer to get 5 acres. They were no bulldozers to do the scrubbing; it was all done by hand.

I am one who has done it.

Then did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home-prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

We home grow everything yet unless we want a little change like a tiny salmon or a little change but we are still scimping. We had to scrape to save so much in the early days it sorta gets in your bones. So you carry help it the boy get after me about hardy thing I am a widow women now so my youngest son work the farm & I help him out.

Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising prices, problems of storage, shortages, and other details. Use back of page if more space is needed.

We went to Forester in early days for a sack flour 15 miles & the road were so bad they had one-a sack flour in store we had to borrow a baken flour of Mr. Hanna at Forester after going 15 miles over roads when the horses was fairly down & got stuck in mud hole & we lost our horse to get-a team steer as the roads was so bad they were slow but they got us there & back. I made butter from 10 cows & took it to store & got 15 cents per lb. So it was good butter as that was my trade in the Old Country & I know everything about farming so I not making things worse nor they were for they were as bad as they could be.
I hope this will let you see what the poor homesteaders had to go through to get 10 Dollar farm so that 39 years ago.

Mr. H. Hill
Carlea, Sask.

Our Country is between Nipawin & Achesfield on S.W. 19-48+13 west of the second & the land was so wet for 3 years with the leaves down one could do nothing till a fire came through & the men that was in went to work with shovel & pick & made a ditch at the bottom of the road 5 miles & it washed out 10 feet the first year, they did then work free gratis as nobody could walk around the log buildings with dry feet then in 1916 the government spent little money & opened up a mile more ditch & brought them all the way from Beiseker to do the work & there was lots of rain & swamp with family in Carlea District how would I be glad of the money to help them along including ourselves, We lost horses & cattle, the horses died with swamp fever & they could not travel in these wet slush without valley down. It was quite a job to get enough food in to feed the family as one could nearly starve before putting the poor horses over the poor roads we had. It a good country now but it was the pioneers who made it.
